three-forces-story.text: The Ancient Problem. Long before computers existed, humans faced a simple challenge: How do we calculate things faster? From counting sheep to tracking stars, we needed tools to extend our minds.
Stone: The Foundation. The first computers were made of stone—the abacus! Today, we still use stone. Silicon, refined from sand and rock, forms the foundation of every computer chip in existence.
Lightning: The Power. From Benjamin Franklin's kite to modern power grids, we learned to harness electricity. This same lightning-force now flows through every circuit, bringing machines to life.
Magnetism: The Memory. Magnets have a superpower—they remember which way they're pointing! North or south, on or off. This simple property became the foundation of all digital storage.
The Transistor Revolution. In 1947, scientists combined silicon and electricity to create the transistor—a tiny switch smaller than a grain of sand. It turns on and off billions of times per second!
Modern Computing. Today, your phone has 15 billion transistors, each smaller than a virus. The three ancient forces—stone, lightning, and magnetism—work together in your pocket!

binary-story.text: The Humble Switch. A transistor is just a tiny switch. It can be ON or OFF. That's it! But here's the magic—with enough switches working together, we can represent anything.
Binary: Zeros and Ones. We call ON a 'one' and OFF a 'zero'. This two-symbol system is called binary. It's the only language computers truly understand.
Position Matters. In binary, each position represents a power of two. From right to left: 1, 2, 4, 8, 16, and so on. The position of each 1 determines its value!
Converting Binary. To convert binary to decimal, just add up the positions with 1s. For example, 1010 means 8 plus 0 plus 2 plus 0, which equals 10!
Everything is Binary. Text, images, music, videos—everything on your computer is stored as patterns of ones and zeros. This lesson you're reading right now? Just a very long binary number!

navigation-story.text: The Library Analogy. Imagine a library with millions of books but no organization—just books scattered everywhere. Finding anything would be impossible! Computers face the same challenge.
Folders Organize Everything. The solution? Folders! Just like a filing cabinet, computers organize files into folders. Folders can contain other folders, creating a tree-like structure.
Paths: File Addresses. Every file has an address called a path. Like slash Users slash YourName slash Projects slash hello.py. It tells the computer exactly where to find your file.
The Terminal. Before pretty icons, there was only the terminal—a text-based interface where you type commands directly to the computer. Every developer uses it daily!
Essential Commands. With just a few commands, you can navigate anywhere! 'pwd' shows where you are, 'ls' lists what's here, and 'cd' moves you to a new folder. You're in control!
